paper_metadata.title: Microtubule-Stabilizer Epothilone B Delays Anesthetic-Induced Unconsciousness in Rats

evidence.brief_mechanism: Stabilizing microtubules with epothilone B increased the latency to isoflurane-induced loss of righting response.
evidence.method: behavior (loss-of-righting response), pharmacological manipulation (epothilone B), blinded within-subject design, estimation graphics/statistics

text_refs.quote: Average LORR latency increased after epoB injection... Figure 1 shows the average pre- and post-epoB LORR latencies (±SE) for each rat. Seven of the eight rats exhibited increased average LORR latencies in the epoB condition.
text_refs.interpretation: Blinded, within-subject pharmacological stabilization of microtubules (epoB) causally increased time-to-unconsciousness (LORR), directly supporting a manipulable substrate that modulates the anesthesia-induced state change relevant to consciousness science in the brain .

text_refs.quote: This is not enough to plausibly account for the 69 s average LORR latency increase we observed in the post-epoB period as compared with the pre-epoB period.
text_refs.interpretation: Control analyses argue that tolerance cannot explain the observed 69 s increase, strengthening the causal link between MT stabilization and delayed loss of consciousness under isoflurane .

text_refs.quote: In order to quantitatively assess the functional relevance of MTs as one of the anesthetic targets contributing to loss of consciousness, we administered the MT-stabilizing drug epothilone B (epoB) to a group of rats and compared their times to fall unconscious under isoflurane anesthesia before and after epoB treatment.
text_refs.interpretation: The study was explicitly designed to test whether manipulating microtubules changes access to the anesthetic-induced unconscious state, aligning with causal-intervention approaches in consciousness research .

figure_refs.caption_quote: Figure 1. Average LORR latency for each rat in anesthesia sessions before and after epoB injection. Seven of eight rats show higher average LORR latency in the post-epoB injection condition.
figure_refs.interpretation_short: Per-rat data show epoB-associated increases in LORR latency, visualizing the intervention’s causal impact on the anesthesia-induced transition .

figure_refs.caption_quote: Figure 2. Average LORR latency increased after epoB injection... The average LORR latency is 69 s higher in the post-epoB condition as compared with the pre-epoB average, and this difference is statistically significant...
figure_refs.interpretation_short: Estimation plot quantifies a significant 69 s increase in time to LORR after MT stabilization, evidencing causal control over the unconsciousness boundary .

evidence.limitations: Outcome is a behavioral proxy (LORR) rather than a direct neural readout; emergence latencies were too variable to interpret due to injection timing; tolerance/interval effects required modeling and auxiliary cohorts to rule out as confounds .

evidence.brief_mechanism: Quantified onset timing of the anesthesia-induced transition to unconsciousness (LORR) and its modulation across sessions and conditions.
evidence.method: behavioral state assay (LORR), longitudinal session-wise analysis, linear fits of latency time courses

text_refs.quote: Based on linear fits (solid lines), LORR latencies decreased on average by 1.3 s/d for the pre-epoB experiments (A) and increased by 4.5 s/d for the post-epoB sessions (B), 0.97 s/d for the tolerance group (C), and 4.5 s/d for the tolerance group after a 41 d pause in anesthesia sessions (D).
text_refs.interpretation: Session-wise dynamics quantify how the timing of the conscious-to-unconscious transition shifts under different conditions, highlighting abrupt, controllable state boundary properties relevant to state transition analyses in consciousness research .

figure_refs.caption_quote: Figure 3. LORR latency time courses, for pre-epoB sessions (A), post-epoB sessions (B) for the main experimental group... and for another group of four “tolerance” rats not exposed to epoB (C,D).
figure_refs.interpretation_short: Time-course plots display how the onset of unconsciousness varies across regimes (pre/post-epoB and tolerance), consistent with modulated state transition dynamics under anesthesia .

table_refs.caption_quote: Table 3. Linear estimates of tolerance development due to repeated anesthesia sessions, in the main experimental group before and after epoB injection, and the tolerance group before and after a 41 d pause in anesthesia sessions

evidence.limitations: LORR marks a behavioral state switch without direct neural signatures (e.g., P3b/ignition, oscillatory markers), and timing is at seconds scale, limiting inferences about rapid neural state transitions.
